id: median of the absolute deviations of observations from the average which may be the arithmetic mean, the median or the mode
name: median of the absolute deviations of observations from the average which may be the arithmetic mean, the median or the mode

id: The most widely used measure of dispersion of a frequency distribution introduced by K. Pearson (1893). It is equal to the positive square root of the variance. The standard deviation should not be confused with the root mean square deviation.
name: The most widely used measure of dispersion of a frequency distribution introduced by K. Pearson (1893). It is equal to the positive square root of the variance. The standard deviation should not be confused with the root mean square deviation.

id: A common aim of statistical analysis is to produce information about some chosen population. In statistical inference, a subset of the population (a statistical sample) is chosen to represent the population in a statistical analysis. If a sample is chosen properly, characteristics of the entire population that the sample is drawn from can be estimated from corresponding characteristics of the sample.
name: A common aim of statistical analysis is to produce information about some chosen population. In statistical inference, a subset of the population (a statistical sample) is chosen to represent the population in a statistical analysis. If a sample is chosen properly, characteristics of the entire population that the sample is drawn from can be estimated from corresponding characteristics of the sample.

id: A mathematical device or number which is used to express the observation (e.g., price level, volume of trade, relative amount etc.) of a given period, in comparison with that of a prior period.
name: A mathematical device or number which is used to express the observation (e.g., price level, volume of trade, relative amount etc.) of a given period, in comparison with that of a prior period.

id: statistical universe filtered by time and region
name: statistical universe filtered by time and region

id: Although they are both designed to measure performance, KPIs and metrics have different characteristics and are used by businesses in different ways. Metrics are measures used to track progress and evaluate success, while KPIs are metrics tied to specific goals during a certain period of time. KPIs are designed to align with business goals and targets, while metrics evaluate the performance of particular processes.
name: Although they are both designed to measure performance, KPIs and metrics have different characteristics and are used by businesses in different ways. Metrics are measures used to track progress and evaluate success, while KPIs are metrics tied to specific goals during a certain period of time. KPIs are designed to align with business goals and targets, while metrics evaluate the performance of particular processes.

id: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to eliminate the redundant 'calculation formula' concept and eliminate the property hasOperand, which is not used anywhere and whose definition is circular.
name: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to eliminate the redundant 'calculation formula' concept and eliminate the property hasOperand, which is not used anywhere and whose definition is circular.

id: value of the variate dividing the total frequency of a data sample, population, or probability distribution, into two halves
name: value of the variate dividing the total frequency of a data sample, population, or probability distribution, into two halves

id: indicates the number of elements in a given universe
name: indicates the number of elements in a given universe

id: collection representing the total membership, or 'universe', of people, resources, products, services, events, or entities of interest for some question, experiment, survey or statistical program
name: collection representing the total membership, or 'universe', of people, resources, products, services, events, or entities of interest for some question, experiment, survey or statistical program

id: specifies a concise way of expressing information symbolically, as in a mathematical or chemical formula
name: specifies a concise way of expressing information symbolically, as in a mathematical or chemical formula

id: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to eliminate unused imports.
name: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to eliminate unused imports.

id: rule expressed in letters and symbols that consists of at least one expression
name: rule expressed in letters and symbols that consists of at least one expression

id: The central point can be the mean, median, mode, or the result of another measure of central tendency. Absolute deviation is the distance between each value in the data set and that data set's mean or median.
name: The central point can be the mean, median, mode, or the result of another measure of central tendency. Absolute deviation is the distance between each value in the data set and that data set's mean or median.

id: When unqualified, the mean usually refers to the expectation of a variate, or to the arithmetic mean of a sample used as an estimate of the expectation.
name: When unqualified, the mean usually refers to the expectation of a variate, or to the arithmetic mean of a sample used as an estimate of the expectation.

id: Common examples of measures of statistical dispersion are the variance, standard deviation, and interquartile range. The collection size argument, above, represents the number of elements in the set, if known. The collection of values under consideration is represented as a structured collection in FIBO, typically a sample set derived from a finite population.
name: Common examples of measures of statistical dispersion are the variance, standard deviation, and interquartile range. The collection size argument, above, represents the number of elements in the set, if known. The collection of values under consideration is represented as a structured collection in FIBO, typically a sample set derived from a finite population.

id: Standard deviation applied to the annual rate of return of an investment provides insights on the historical volatility of that investment. The greater the standard deviation of the price of a security, the greater the volatility. Multiplying monthly standard deviation by the square root of twelve (12) is an industry standard method of approximating annualized standard deviations of monthly returns.
name: Standard deviation applied to the annual rate of return of an investment provides insights on the historical volatility of that investment. The greater the standard deviation of the price of a security, the greater the volatility. Multiplying monthly standard deviation by the square root of twelve (12) is an industry standard method of approximating annualized standard deviations of monthly returns.

id: This measure represents the middle value (if n is odd) or the average of the two middle values (if n is even) in an ordered list of data values. The median divides the total frequency distribution into two equal parts: one-half of the cases fall below the median and one-half of the cases exceed the median.
name: This measure represents the middle value (if n is odd) or the average of the two middle values (if n is even) in an ordered list of data values. The median divides the total frequency distribution into two equal parts: one-half of the cases fall below the median and one-half of the cases exceed the median.

id: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to eliminate deprecated elements.
name: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to eliminate deprecated elements.

id: statistical measure that is constrained by features, quantity kinds or units that refine how it is calculated
name: statistical measure that is constrained by features, quantity kinds or units that refine how it is calculated

id: isCharacterizedBy, and eliminate duplicate properties that were not used anywhere.
name: isCharacterizedBy, and eliminate duplicate properties that were not used anywhere.

id: A statistical universe can be a group of actually existing objects (e.g. the set of all stars within the Milky Way galaxy) or a hypothetical and potentially infinite group of objects conceived as a generalization from experience (e.g. the set of all possible hands in a game of poker).
name: A statistical universe can be a group of actually existing objects (e.g. the set of all stars within the Milky Way galaxy) or a hypothetical and potentially infinite group of objects conceived as a generalization from experience (e.g. the set of all possible hands in a game of poker).

id: indicates the coverage period for which the measure is applicable expressed in months
name: indicates the coverage period for which the measure is applicable expressed in months

id: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to use the Commons Ontology Library (Commons) rather than the OMG's Languages, Countries and Codes (LCC), eliminating redundancies in FIBO as appropriate.
name: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to use the Commons Ontology Library (Commons) rather than the OMG's Languages, Countries and Codes (LCC), eliminating redundancies in FIBO as appropriate.

id: While the arithmetic mean is often used to report central tendencies, it is not a robust statistic, meaning that it is greatly influenced by outliers (values that are very much larger or smaller than most of the values). Notably, for skewed distributions, such as the distribution of income for which a few people's incomes are substantially greater than most people's, the arithmetic mean may not accord with one's notion of 'middle', and robust statistics, such as the median, may be a better description of central tendency.
name: While the arithmetic mean is often used to report central tendencies, it is not a robust statistic, meaning that it is greatly influenced by outliers (values that are very much larger or smaller than most of the values). Notably, for skewed distributions, such as the distribution of income for which a few people's incomes are substantially greater than most people's, the arithmetic mean may not accord with one's notion of 'middle', and robust statistics, such as the median, may be a better description of central tendency.

id: The geometric mean is defined as the nth root of the product of n numbers. A geometric mean is often used when comparing different items - finding a single 'figure of merit' for these items - when each item has multiple properties that have different numeric ranges. For example, the geometric mean can give a meaningful 'average' to compare two companies which are each rated at 0 to 5 for their environmental sustainability, and are rated at 0 to 100 for their financial viability. If an arithmetic mean were used instead of a geometric mean, the financial viability is given more weight because its numeric range is larger - so a small percentage change in the financial rating (e.g. going from 80 to 90) makes a much larger difference in the arithmetic mean than a large percentage change in environmental sustainability (e.g. going from 2 to 5).
name: The geometric mean is defined as the nth root of the product of n numbers. A geometric mean is often used when comparing different items - finding a single 'figure of merit' for these items - when each item has multiple properties that have different numeric ranges. For example, the geometric mean can give a meaningful 'average' to compare two companies which are each rated at 0 to 5 for their environmental sustainability, and are rated at 0 to 100 for their financial viability. If an arithmetic mean were used instead of a geometric mean, the financial viability is given more weight because its numeric range is larger - so a small percentage change in the financial rating (e.g. going from 80 to 90) makes a much larger difference in the arithmetic mean than a large percentage change in environmental sustainability (e.g. going from 2 to 5).

id: indicates the number of elements in some document, table, or other resource (e.g., in a report, table)
name: indicates the number of elements in some document, table, or other resource (e.g., in a report, table)

id: Given a sample size of 1000, and a population of 300M, then the chance that any individual is selected is 1 in 300K. In that case, 300K is the weight assigned to each of the elements in the sample.
name: Given a sample size of 1000, and a population of 300M, then the chance that any individual is selected is 1 in 300K. In that case, 300K is the weight assigned to each of the elements in the sample.

id: standard deviation for some measure over a specific reference period
name: standard deviation for some measure over a specific reference period

id: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to update the reference link for ratio.
name: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to update the reference link for ratio.

id: Note that (1) the anchor date reflects the start of the current series, such as 1982-1984 for the CPI, (2) the fixed comparative date might be something like March 2009, if one is comparing a current index against its value at the end of the great recession, (3) the relative comparative date might be something like a month or year ago, depending on the analysis requirements, and (4) the relative comparative period might be a 3 month average prior value, again depending on the analysis requirements.
name: Note that (1) the anchor date reflects the start of the current series, such as 1982-1984 for the CPI, (2) the fixed comparative date might be something like March 2009, if one is comparing a current index against its value at the end of the great recession, (3) the relative comparative date might be something like a month or year ago, depending on the analysis requirements, and (4) the relative comparative period might be a 3 month average prior value, again depending on the analysis requirements.

id: degree of scatter or variability shown by observations
name: degree of scatter or variability shown by observations

id: population for which it is possible to count its units
name: population for which it is possible to count its units

id: specifies a date against which the value of a scoped measure is compared (e.g., one month prior, three months prior, etc., and typically against a prior release or average over prior releases)
name: specifies a date against which the value of a scoped measure is compared (e.g., one month prior, three months prior, etc., and typically against a prior release or average over prior releases)

id: Examples include profits, sales numbers, employee turnover and average annual expenses.
name: Examples include profits, sales numbers, employee turnover and average annual expenses.

id: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to eliminate hygiene issues related to text formatting and eliminate dead or outdated references.
name: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to eliminate hygiene issues related to text formatting and eliminate dead or outdated references.

id: specifies the date on which something is published
name: specifies the date on which something is published

id: specifies the quantity value that is subtracted from something
name: specifies the quantity value that is subtracted from something

id: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified per the FIBO 2.0 RFC.
name: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified per the FIBO 2.0 RFC.

id: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to add a synonym of 'average' to arithmetic mean.
name: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to add a synonym of 'average' to arithmetic mean.

id: With respect to discrete calculations, weighting functions are positive functions defined on discrete sets, such as weighted sums and weighted averages.
name: With respect to discrete calculations, weighting functions are positive functions defined on discrete sets, such as weighted sums and weighted averages.

id: physical location that is defined per some program for designating geographic regions for the purposes of tabulating and presenting statistical data
name: physical location that is defined per some program for designating geographic regions for the purposes of tabulating and presenting statistical data

id: indicates the date and time that the measurement was taken
name: indicates the date and time that the measurement was taken

id: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to add the concept of a weighting algorithm.
name: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to add the concept of a weighting algorithm.

id: This ontology provides mathematical abstractions for use in other ontologies, including for example the basic components of formulae, parameters and values.
name: This ontology provides mathematical abstractions for use in other ontologies, including for example the basic components of formulae, parameters and values.

id: sum of a collection of numbers divided by the number of numbers in the collection
name: sum of a collection of numbers divided by the number of numbers in the collection

id: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to use the CombinedDateTime datatype for greater flexibility in analytics and integrate the generic statistical measures and measurements from the economic indicators ontology to FND to facilitate broader use.
name: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to use the CombinedDateTime datatype for greater flexibility in analytics and integrate the generic statistical measures and measurements from the economic indicators ontology to FND to facilitate broader use.

id: quantity by which amounts differ; the remainder left after subtraction of one value from another
name: quantity by which amounts differ; the remainder left after subtraction of one value from another

id: square root of variance that measures the spread or dispersion around the mean of a data set
name: square root of variance that measures the spread or dispersion around the mean of a data set

id: Analytics.rdf version of the ontology was modified to replace content that is now available in the OMG Commons Ontology Library (Commons) v1.1 (FND-380).
name: Analytics.rdf version of the ontology was modified to replace content that is now available in the OMG Commons Ontology Library (Commons) v1.1 (FND-380).

id: The basic advantage of the median in describing data compared to the mean is that it is not skewed by extremely large or small values, and may provide a better idea of a 'typical' value.
name: The basic advantage of the median in describing data compared to the mean is that it is not skewed by extremely large or small values, and may provide a better idea of a 'typical' value.

id: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to augment the definition of ratio with a synonym of rate and eliminate the circularity in the definition of standard deviation.
name: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to augment the definition of ratio with a synonym of rate and eliminate the circularity in the definition of standard deviation.

id: A measure of statistical dispersion is a nonnegative real number that is zero if all the data are the same and increases as the data become more diverse.
name: A measure of statistical dispersion is a nonnegative real number that is zero if all the data are the same and increases as the data become more diverse.

id: measure of the extent to which the estimate of a characteristic from different possible samples of the same size and the same design differ from one another
name: measure of the extent to which the estimate of a characteristic from different possible samples of the same size and the same design differ from one another

id: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to use the Commons Ontology Library (Commons) Annotation Vocabulary rather than the OMG's Specification Metadata vocabulary.
name: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to use the Commons Ontology Library (Commons) Annotation Vocabulary rather than the OMG's Specification Metadata vocabulary.

id: For certain calculations, such as certain measures of dispersion, date value pairs are expected as input, in other words, a dated structured collection.
name: For certain calculations, such as certain measures of dispersion, date value pairs are expected as input, in other words, a dated structured collection.

id: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to address issue FIBOFND11-20, which added the definition of Calculation and corrected a reasoning issue related to the use of a custom datatype.
name: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to address issue FIBOFND11-20, which added the definition of Calculation and corrected a reasoning issue related to the use of a custom datatype.

id: This ontology was added to Foundations in advance of the June 2014 Boston meeting in support of the IND RFC.
name: This ontology was added to Foundations in advance of the June 2014 Boston meeting in support of the IND RFC.

id: program that presents a detailed investigation and analysis of a subject or situation involving one or more studies or surveys
name: program that presents a detailed investigation and analysis of a subject or situation involving one or more studies or surveys

id: average of the absolute deviations from a central point
name: average of the absolute deviations from a central point

id: measure of spread, calculated as the average squared deviation of each number from the mean of a data set
name: measure of spread, calculated as the average squared deviation of each number from the mean of a data set

id: Analytics.rdf version of the ontology was modified to replace additional content that is now available in the OMG Commons Ontology Library (Commons) v1.1 (FND-380) and to move the concept of an anchor date to Financial Dates (FBC-317).
name: Analytics.rdf version of the ontology was modified to replace additional content that is now available in the OMG Commons Ontology Library (Commons) v1.1 (FND-380) and to move the concept of an anchor date to Financial Dates (FBC-317).

id: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to revise numeric index to be called numeric index value, and revise its definition to include a reference date, change its parent to quantity value, and move base date and period to scoped measure.
name: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to revise numeric index to be called numeric index value, and revise its definition to include a reference date, change its parent to quantity value, and move base date and period to scoped measure.

id: specifies a recurrence interval (monthly, quarterly, annual) that a statistical measure reflects
name: specifies a recurrence interval (monthly, quarterly, annual) that a statistical measure reflects

id: specifies a collection of values that represent planned or projected goals or objectives for some something over time
name: specifies a collection of values that represent planned or projected goals or objectives for some something over time

id: It is usually measured as an average deviation about some central value (e.g. mean deviation, standard deviation) or by an order statistic (e.g. quartile deviation, range) but may also be a mean of deviations of values among themselves (e.g. Gini's mean difference and also standard deviation).
name: It is usually measured as an average deviation about some central value (e.g. mean deviation, standard deviation) or by an order statistic (e.g. quartile deviation, range) but may also be a mean of deviations of values among themselves (e.g. Gini's mean difference and also standard deviation).

id: mean that indicates the central tendency or typical value of a set of numbers by using the product of their values (as opposed to the arithmetic mean which uses their sum)
name: mean that indicates the central tendency or typical value of a set of numbers by using the product of their values (as opposed to the arithmetic mean which uses their sum)

id: Analytics.rdf version of the ontology was modified to eliminate deprecations that are more than 6 months old.
name: Analytics.rdf version of the ontology was modified to eliminate deprecations that are more than 6 months old.

id: summary (means, mode, total, index, etc.) of the individual quantitative variable values for the statistical units in a specific group (study domain)
name: summary (means, mode, total, index, etc.) of the individual quantitative variable values for the statistical units in a specific group (study domain)

id: Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) are the critical (key) quantifiable indicators of progress toward an intended result. KPIs provide a focus for strategic and operational improvement, create an analytical basis for decision making and help focus attention on what matters most. Managing with the use of KPIs includes setting targets (the desired level of performance) and tracking progress against those targets.
name: Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) are the critical (key) quantifiable indicators of progress toward an intended result. KPIs provide a focus for strategic and operational improvement, create an analytical basis for decision making and help focus attention on what matters most. Managing with the use of KPIs includes setting targets (the desired level of performance) and tracking progress against those targets.

id: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to expand the definition of release date and release date and time and to make a statistical area identifier a subclass of geographic region identifier.
name: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to expand the definition of release date and release date and time and to make a statistical area identifier a subclass of geographic region identifier.

id: specifies the a specific date, such as the end of the last recession (e.g., March 2009) against which the scoped measure is compared
name: specifies the a specific date, such as the end of the last recession (e.g., March 2009) against which the scoped measure is compared

id: Analytics.rdf version of the ontology was modified to eliminate elements that have been deprecated for several quarters (FND-386) and to add the concept of a key performance indicator (KPI) (LOAN-169).
name: Analytics.rdf version of the ontology was modified to eliminate elements that have been deprecated for several quarters (FND-386) and to add the concept of a key performance indicator (KPI) (LOAN-169).

id: Statistical measures may consist of several orthogonal characteristics, including (a) whether they reflect an estimate or variable, (b) the datatype, or from a FIBO perspective, nature of the measure (e.g., index, total, ratio, percent, percent change, mean, others), (c) the population (or the universe that applies to the highest level if defined in general) to which the measure applies, and (d) any relevant aspects used to subset or stratify a measure, (i.e., make them apply to a smaller universe).
name: Statistical measures may consist of several orthogonal characteristics, including (a) whether they reflect an estimate or variable, (b) the datatype, or from a FIBO perspective, nature of the measure (e.g., index, total, ratio, percent, percent change, mean, others), (c) the population (or the universe that applies to the highest level if defined in general) to which the measure applies, and (d) any relevant aspects used to subset or stratify a measure, (i.e., make them apply to a smaller universe).

id: high-level description of the approach taken to obtain the result
name: high-level description of the approach taken to obtain the result

id: numeric value of some aggregate relative to the value of that aggregate as of some date
name: numeric value of some aggregate relative to the value of that aggregate as of some date

id: most common measure of central tendency; the average of a set of numbers
name: most common measure of central tendency; the average of a set of numbers

name: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to make statistical program a subclass of program and revised restrictions on statistical program to better reflect its intent.

id: specifies the date and time on which something is published
name: specifies the date and time on which something is published

id: For certain indices, one of the most common weighting factor is by market capitalization. In that case, each of the elements in the basket is multiplied by its market cap to determine its relative importance to the basket overall.
name: For certain indices, one of the most common weighting factor is by market capitalization. In that case, each of the elements in the basket is multiplied by its market cap to determine its relative importance to the basket overall.

id: indicates the number of elements in a given population
name: indicates the number of elements in a given population

id: indicates an amount given to increase or decrease the importance of an item
name: indicates an amount given to increase or decrease the importance of an item

id: A release date is typically a date fixed in advance for the release of a film, recording, document, report, or product or publication.
name: A release date is typically a date fixed in advance for the release of a film, recording, document, report, or product or publication.

id: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to eliminate duplication with concepts in LCC, merge countries with locations, and correct a restriction on qualified measure.
name: Analytics.rdf version of this ontology was modified to eliminate duplication with concepts in LCC, merge countries with locations, and correct a restriction on qualified measure.

id: The word 'sampling' can usually be omitted, as being defined by the context or otherwise understood. The sampling variance of a statistic is the square of its standard error.
name: The word 'sampling' can usually be omitted, as being defined by the context or otherwise understood. The sampling variance of a statistic is the square of its standard error.

id: specifies a reference (baseline) recurrence interval for which a given measure applies
name: specifies a reference (baseline) recurrence interval for which a given measure applies

id: specifies a period (typically a prior period) against which the scoped measure is compared, such as an average set of values for some period of time compared with a more recent or projected average for a forward looking period of time
name: specifies a period (typically a prior period) against which the scoped measure is compared, such as an average set of values for some period of time compared with a more recent or projected average for a forward looking period of time

id: While standard deviation is the most widely-used measure of spread, using squared deviations, it may not be the most robust.
name: While standard deviation is the most widely-used measure of spread, using squared deviations, it may not be the most robust.

id: specifies the quantity value from which something is subtracted; the value that is diminished
name: specifies the quantity value from which something is subtracted; the value that is diminished

id: specifies a collection of values over which some analysis is performed
name: specifies a collection of values over which some analysis is performed

id: measurable target that indicates how an individual or business is performing in terms of meeting its goals
name: measurable target that indicates how an individual or business is performing in terms of meeting its goals

id: qualified measure that is constrained by filters on the statistical population to which it applies
name: qualified measure that is constrained by filters on the statistical population to which it applies

id: indicates whether the measure reflects an estimate (approximation) or not
name: indicates whether the measure reflects an estimate (approximation) or not

id: expression or function that determines the relative importance or influence of a given element of a set with respect to the whole
name: expression or function that determines the relative importance or influence of a given element of a set with respect to the whole

id: identifier for a physical location that is defined per a nationally consistent program for designating geographic regions for the purposes of tabulating and presenting statistical data
name: identifier for a physical location that is defined per a nationally consistent program for designating geographic regions for the purposes of tabulating and presenting statistical data
